Request Description: Request any and all documents containing information related to Wildlife Services' (WS) intentional and unintentional take of dogs (Canisfamiliaris) and cats (Felis catus) in the course of WS activities from January 2008 to present. This request includes, but is not limited to: 1. All reviews, evaluations, communications and other documents generated in the course of or as a result of the capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats in the course of WS' wildlife damage management efforts or other activities; 2. All complaints submitted by any party concerning WS' intentional or unintentional capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats; 3. APHIS's responses to all complaints submitted by any party concerning WS' intentional or unintentional capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats; 4. All records reflecting disciplinary action taken against any WS employee for unauthorized or otherwise improper capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats; 5. All records reflecting formal or informal authorizations for capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats; 6. The results of any internal reviews of WS' intentional or unintentional capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats; 7. All records documenting the intentional or unintentional capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats, including those which reflect the number of dogs and cats taken by WS and the methods used, the underlying rationale, and the alternatives considered for such take; and 8. Records of all corrective action taken by APHIS in response to unauthorized or otherwise improper capture, injury or killing of dogs or cats by any WS employee, contractor or volunteer.

Requesting a digital copy of the following documents: 1.) A spreadsheet listing each privately-owned facility in the United States in which cervids such as deer, elk or moose are farmed, kept or harvested, including fenced hunting preserves. Such a digital list may include, but not limited to, digital fields listing the owner's name, the name of the facility, its address, the number and type of animals on site, and the date the facility was first recorded as keeping deer, elk or moose. 2.) A spreadsheet or list of captive cervid facilities in which at any time chronic wasting disease was discovered on site or in captive cervids. Such a list may include, but not be limited to, the name, geographic location, owner of the facility, the dates at which animals were determined to be positive or the disease was discovered, and the number of infected and/or potentially infected animals. 3.) A spreadsheet or list of captive cervid facilities in which at any time bovine tuberculosis was discovered on site or in captive cervids. Such a list may include, but not limited to, the name, geographic location, owner of the facility, the dates at which animals were determined to be positive or disease was discovered, and the number of infected and/or potentially infected animals. 4.) A spreadsheet or list of captive cervid facilities in which at any time brucellosis was discovered on site or in captive cervid. Such a list may include, but not limited to, the name, the geographic location, owner of the facility, the dates at which animals were determined to be positive or the disease was discovered, and the number of infected and/or potentially infected animals. 5.) The raw digital data used to create the following or similar online maps: http://www.aphis.usda.gov/anim al_health/animal_disease/cwd/d ownloads/distibution_cwd.pdf. Public Information Officer Workabeba "Abby" Yigsaw, a UADA Public Affairs Specialist, indicated an email that the USDA has these records in its possession. 6.) The raw digital data used to create any older versions of the online maps requested in the bullet point above 7.) Any reports or analysis conducted by the Center for Epidemiology and Animal Health or any other wing of the USDA veterinary service department that discusses epidemiologic-transmission between and among the captive cervid facilities in the United States

Requesting the Regulatory Impact Analysis & Initial Regulatory Flexibility Analysis issued April 2012 for Proposed Rule APHIS-2011-0003 RIN 0579-AD57.   Page 13, first paragraph states, "During a program audit that was completed in 2010, USDA's Office of Inspection General found consumers who purchased dogs over the Internet had encountered health problems with their dogs."                                                     --Provide copies of the consumer complaints referenced in the above statement.

The Regulatory Impact Analysis & Initial Regulatory Flexibility Analysis (Analysis) issued April 2012 for Proposed Rule APHIS-2011-0003 RIN 0579-AD57, Pages 15 and 16 discuss Potentially Affected Small Entities. The Analysis states, “The entities affected by the proposed rule are likely to be considered small.” The Analysis further states, “The Small Business Administration (SBA) has established guidelines for determining which entities are to be considered small. Pet stores are identified in the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) category 453910, Pet and Pet Supplies Stores. This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in retailing pets, pet foods, and pet supplies. The small-entity standard for this industry is annual sales of not more than $19 million. In 2007, there were about 8,880 pet and pet supply stores in the United States.” In addition the Analysis states, “Establishments primarily engaged in retailing pets, pet foods, and pet supplies via electronic home shopping, mail-order, or direct sale are classified within NAICS subsector 454, Nonstore Retailers, and specifically, within NAICS category 4541112, Electronic Shopping, Specialized Merchandise. An entity in this category is considered small if it generates not more than $30 million in annual sales. In 2007, there were about 13,500 establishments in NAICS category 4541112, with average sales of $5.4 million.” The Analysis states on page 10, “Although we have attempted to estimate the impact of this proposed rule, we do not currently have enough information to fully assess it, particularly information on the number of entities that may be affected, or the breadth of operational changes that may occur at affected entities as a result.” APHIS properly identified the Proposed Rule to be “significant for the purposes of Executive Orders 12866 and 13563” and made the assumption that the affected entities were likely to be small entities, presumably as defined by the Small Business Administration (SBA). Please provide copies of all correspondence between APHIS and offices of the Small Business Administration between May 2011 and May 2012 pertaining to the Proposed Rule and potential impact on small entities. Digital copies are preferred. Please advise if fees for providing the documents that I have requested will exceed $100.00

Repeat Violation: 2.131 (c) (1) Handling of animals. “Barrier shall be made so that the public cannot gain access to the enclosure”; 2. 3.80 (a) (2) (ix) Primary Enclosures. “These surfaces shall be repaired or resurfaced to make them readily cleaned & sanitized.” Correct by February 1, 2013; 3. 3.127 (c) Facilities, Outdoor. “The depression in the dirt shall be corrected so that excess water is rapidly eliminated. Requesting a copy of any and all data in the possession of APHIS at USDA related to any theft or loss of select agents or toxins from 2008-present. This information would likely be gathered by APHIS after it received an APHIS Form 3 submitted to your agency for any veterinary or other entity that may deal with registered select agents or toxins who has had one lost or stolen. We are specifically NOT requesting information about exposures which may have taken place which may also have resulted in the filing of a Form 3 with APHIS. In that regard, please provide the following documents or data: 1.) Please provide in electronic form if possible the following fields of data which are incorporated on the Form 3: the date of the theft or loss, the date of notification to APHIS, the type of notification (email, fax, telephone), state the theft or the loss took place in/was reported from, type of incident (theft, loss, otherwise unaccounted for, etc.), the time of the incident, date of last inventory, name of select agent or toxin missing, characterization of agent (e.g. strain, atcc#), quantity/amount lost or missing or stolen, whether or not an internal review at the lab has been initiated at the location it was lost to prevent further loss, and any information indicating whether or not the select agent or toxin has since been located (and if so, when it was located).

Documents indication or reflecting properties owned and the owners of Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch; 3. All violations reported; 4. Any reports submitted by Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch; 5. Any correspondence received from Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch or from any person or persons acting on its behalf; 6. Any correspondence from the Department of Agriculture to Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch, or to any person or persons on its behalf; 7. Any reports or documents received from other organizations or entities, including but not limited to the Humane Society of the United States, regarding Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch; 8. Any audio tapes, videotapes and photographs regarding Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch; and 9. Any documents concerning administrative or legal action instituted with respect to Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch.

Organization: The Humane Society of the United States
Request Description: Request all data maintained by APHIS recording the amounts of funds transferred to U.S. States to assist the states in any and all activities undertaken to address Chronic Wasting Disease, Brucellosis, and/or Tuberculosis (“disease”) in captive and wild cervids and bison. Responsive records are to include, but be not limited to, the following, beginning January 1, 2008, through and until the funding was discontinued in 2012: (1) Total dollar amounts of funds allocated to the states to assist them in conducting the following disease-related tasks: a) Surveillance b) Testing and other laboratory costs c) Mitigation and prevention d) Depopulation (sharpshooting) e) Disposal f) Quarantine (such as quarantine of bison suspected to have Brucellosis) g) Indemnity, in cases where a captive animal is seized for testing for one of the aforementioned diseases h) And any other costs related to these diseases for which APHIS provides assisting funds to the states. (2) Data quantifying any funds used by APHIS for the purpose of conducting testing, inspection, or enforcement of standards of the CWD Herd Certification Program, or of any other programs or activities undertaken by APHIS directly to address the above listed diseases; (3) Data be arranged by recipient state. Furthermore, the funds allocated to each state be organized, if possible, by state agency.

Request all agreements through which other agencies, organizations and/or individuals contribute funding, labor and/or other items of value in return for work by the Wildlife Services program run by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS): All qualifying records generated by or in the possession of the USDA, APHIS, and/or Wildlife Services from the August 1997 date that the Animal Damage Control program became the Wildlife Services program, up to the time of fulfillment of this request.
Requesting the most updated list of all individuals who have violated the Commercial Transport of Equines to Slaughter Regulations to date, including fines and actions taken.
Requesting copies of all documents, records, decisions and pictures available 9 CFR violation case #MI10104 against Jeff Hayes from Indiana.
Requesting copies of all documents, records, decisions and pictures available 9 CFR violation case #TX10845 against Raymond Tucker.
Requesting all documents, records, decisions and pictures available 9 CFR violation case #IL07185 against John Birdsong, Randy Ray and Joseph Copas.
Requesting documents pertaining to the Geesebusters complaint of fraud in the USDA Hot Line file Number              .
Requesting any and all information pertaining to a Notice of Alleged Violation (form AI-591) at the Blaine Peach Arch Crossing in 2010.
